I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
1.  The government of Georgia (the government) is investing substantial amounts in the 
infrastructure needed to take advantage of its strategic location, with emphasis on the country’s 
backbone for transit trade comprised of the East–West and North–South transport corridors. 
The East–West Highway is being upgraded (approximately 480 kilometers [km]; 40% completed 
as of end 2017) with the assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), European Investment 
Bank,  Japanese  International  Cooperation  Agency,  and  the World  Bank. The  North–South 
Corridor is a lifeline for Georgian and Armenian economic activities as the only land access to the 
Russian Federation, with a two-way containerized tonnage of approximately 1.3 million tons in 
2015.1 
 
2.  The proposed project will (i) improve the Kvesheti–Kobi road section on the strategically 
important North–South Corridor, and (ii) strengthen the capacity of the Roads Department and 
technical universities on construction, operation, and maintenance of large bridges and tunnels. 
The Kvesheti–Kobi road section, which carries about 3,000–4,000 vehicles per day (70% of cars 
and 30% of trucks and buses; 2017), has very difficult geographical and winter maintenance 
conditions that result in its closure for extended periods during the winter. Further, modern trucks 
cannot pass simultaneously through the existing galleries on this section due to insufficient 
clearance. The traffic discontinuity is a major impediment to meeting the increasing transport 
demand on the North–South Corridor and harnessing the tourism potential of the region (Gudauri 
ski resort, Kazbegi National Park, etc.). 
 
3.  The outcome of the project will be connectivity, access, and safety on the North–South 
Corridor improved. The project will be aligned with the following impacts: (i) economic growth and 
regional connectivity supported (Georgia 2020),2 and (ii) competitive corridors across the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) region established (CAREC Program).3 It is 
consistent with the strategic objectives of ADB’s Country Partnership Strategy 2014–2018 and is 
included in the Country Operations Business Plan for Georgia, 2018–2020. 
 
4.  The project is expected to cost about $550 million. The government has approached the  
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to 
help finance the project. The government will provide counterpart funding of about $130 million 
equivalent to cover taxes and duties, land acquisition and resettlement costs, financing charges, 
and other miscellaneous costs. The Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure will be 
the executing agency and its Roads Department will be the implementing agency. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
5.  The  proposed  transaction  technical  assistance  (TRTA)  will  help  the  government  of 
Georgia (the government) prepare the proposed ensuing project.4 The TRTA will ensure that the 
project  will  be  prepared  to  acceptable  technical,  safeguards,  and  procurement  standards. 
The ensuing project is expected to meet the “high readiness” criteria before Board consideration. 
 
                                                
1  Since January 2015, Armenian exports to the Russian Federation are exempted from any custom duties as it joined 
the Eurasian Economic Union. The Russian Federation is Armenia’s largest trade partner. 
2  Government of Georgia. 2014. Socio-economic Development Strategy of Georgia, “Georgia 2020”. Tbilisi. 
3  ADB. 2014. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy, 2020. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on {Day Month Year}.

2 
6.  Due  diligence.  The  proposed  project  is  very  challenging  from  an  engineering  and 
construction perspective. It will include the longest tunnel in Georgia (about 9 km long) and a 
signature arch bridge that will become a national landmark. Given the project’s complexity and 
safeguards impacts, adequate resources will be required to (i) improve and finalize the safeguard 
documents that are being prepared under savings of on-going ADB and World Bank projects, (ii) 
assist with ensuring procurement of the project’s civil works and consulting services are carried 
out efficiently and effectively; (iii) prepare a climate risk assessment and management report, and 
(iv) assess possible options for tolling of the project road. In addition, the proposed TRTA will help 
enhance communication and engagement with project beneficiaries and affected people through 
tailored communication activities and media. 
 
7.  Procurement support. The Roads Department’s portfolio of projects is rapidly increasing 
with  a  number  of  large  and  complex  projects  that  are  being  prepared  simultaneously. 
The proposed ensuing project include the procurement of three large contracts for civil works and 
construction  supervision  services,  with  a  cumulative  value  estimated  at  $470  million. 
Timely award of these contracts and commencement of construction will require the support of 
an international procurement expert who will based in Tbilisi and work closely with the Roads 
Department. 
 
8.  Capacity development. The implementation of the Roads Department’s program on 
highways improvement will lead to a dramatic increase of its assets, which is exemplified by the 
50 tunnels that will be added in the next five years to the existing 10 tunnels country-wide. 
A similar situation will exist with major bridges. Constructing, operating and maintaining these 
large bridges and tunnels require a skillset that may not exist in the country at the moment. 
The proposed TRTA will assist the Roads Department in learning from specialized experts and 
other road agencies how they can effectively manage their expanding asset base of large bridges 
and tunnels. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
9.  Output 1: Due diligence on the proposed project carried out. This output will include 
preparing safeguards documentation for the environmental and social aspects of the project 
consistent with ADB’s Safeguards Policy Statement 2009, and preparing a gender action plan 
following ADB’s guidelines for such plans. It will also include the preparation and implementation 
of a project communication strategy and action plan. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Procurement  support  provided.  This  output  will  include  assisting  the 
government with advertising the contracts, preparing and managing pre-bid meetings and site 
visits, receiving bids, evaluating bids, preparing bid evaluation reports for government and ADB 
approval, and finalizing contract documentation for award. 
 
11.  Output 3: Capacity of the Roads Department assessed. This output will include (i) the 
preparation of a training needs assessment for the Roads Department and selected technical 
universities, (ii) the preparation and delivery of a peer-learning study tour for selected staff from 
the Roads Department, and (iii) a scoping of the capacity development component envisaged 
under the proposed project.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent, of which $750,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other resources). The

3 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of furnished office accommodation in the 
Roads Department’s premises and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. The government was informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit 
ADB to finance the ensuing project.

and  West  Asia  Department  will  select,  supervise  and  evaluate  the  consultants.

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.5 The consultants will procure the goods and equipment required to 
undertake the services. The TA will require approximately 24 person-months of international 
consultants and 6 person-months of national inputs. The consultants will provide expertise in 
procurement, capacity development, environment, resettlement and social development, and 
communication. The summary of consultants’ required inputs is in Table 2. 
 
15.  International  consultants  will  be  recruited  as  individuals  with  input-based  contracts. 
Two experts in operation and maintenance of large bridges and tunnels will be recruited from a 
Road Agency from a relevant ADB member country. In addition, two person-months of resource 
person contracts will be reserved to allow inputs from highly specialized experts, particularly to 
support the preparation of the climate change assessment and road tolling assessment (para. 6).

1.  Terms of Reference for Consultants

North-South Corridor (Kvesheti–Kobi) Road Project (TA GEO 51257) 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Background 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is providing a technical assistance grant to the 
government  of  Georgia  (the  government)  for  the  preparation  of  the  North-South  Corridor 
(Kvesheti–Kobi) Road Project (the project). The project road covers around 23 kilometers (km) of 
the highway linking the capital Tbilisi with the Russian Federation border at Larsi. The existing 
Kvesheti to Kobi road section, which the project will replace, is around 35 km long, and crosses 
the Jvari Pass at an altitude of around 2,400 meters. 
 
2.  Reflecting the challenging terrain through which the project road passes, it includes 5 
tunnels of total length 10.5 km, one of which is 9 km long, and 6 bridges of total length about 
1.6 km, including a high level concrete arch structure. The project scope will also  include 
improvements to several local roads that connect with the project road. 
 
3.  The Executing Agency for the project will be the Ministry of Regional Development and 
Infrastructure (MRDI) and the Implementing Agency will be MRDI’s Roads Department. MRDI will 
be the Employer for the civil works contracts and the client for the project management and 
contract supervision contract. 
 
4.  ADB will engage international consultants to assist ADB and MRDI with preparing the 
project to the standard required for processing ADB financing. The consultants will be recruited 
in accordance with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
5.  The individual consultants are expected to be recruited by September 2018. The services 
will generally be provided in Tbilisi, and at the project location as required. The MRDI/Roads 
Department will provide the consultants will all reports, documents, and other information that 
they have reasonably available. 
 
B.  Position-based Terms of Reference 
6.  The position-based terms of reference (TOR) for each of the international consultants who 
will undertake the services are presented in the tables below.

graduate qualifications

contracts (including large tunnels and bridges), with a substantial part of this experience 
in projects financed by ADB or other similar international funding agencies. Part of this 
experience should preferably have been in institutional environments similar to those 
prevailing in Georgia.

Experience  Preferably  10  years  of  experience  or  more  in  preparing  and  implementing

Tasks  • Assist MRDI/RD in conducting a Stakeholders’ Mapping to identify key stakeholders,

materials; assist MRDI/RD in setting-up a tracking system, media monitoring as well
